text:
*Feedback request:* brother and I just finished first prototype of Wasp - higher-level programming language for building web apps - would love to get your feedback!
Webpage (with demo): <https://wasp-lang.dev>, Github repo: <https://github.com/wasp-lang/wasp> .
We are still very early / experimental, and current demo is yet far away from our vision, but it should illustrate some basic concepts.
Our main challenge is designing the language so it captures the correct abstractions and is easy to use, while also making it flexible enough to be useful. Plan for now is to find inspiration in current popular frameworks and similar solutions + guide development by specific use cases (we started with Todo App).
Thanks!

Plan for now is to find inspiration in current popular frameworks and similar solutions + guide development by specific use cases (we started with Todo App).

text: <@UCUSW7WVD> love it! Thanks for the rec.

elements.text: love it! Thanks for the rec.

text: To tie this up, I ended up dropping the heatmap vis that was there and just went with a "disappearing key" effects for visualizing the history of the symbols. It was actually sort of interesting how the keyboard is sort of organized in rings with the innermost keys being the oldest and the newest keys being on the periphery. If only there was more time in the day :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
<@UE0ETTCG7>
For value add measurement -  I like these 3 books:- The Mom Test, Microsoft secrets, Competing Against Luck.

For example: Rob Fitzpatrick, bankrupted 3 businesses. Because he did not know how assess the value add of an idea. Also Microsoft had similar problems in the 1990's. People have learned from these failures, and there are now better processes that help with idea validation.

The main idea is to measure the value add of an idea. These 3 books do this in slightly different ways, but they all assess the "value add" by comparing to the current solution. You take the current solution and use that to evaluate new ideas.

Some people call the current solution "As Is" and the proposed solution "To Be".

- Microsoft secrets - It covers many topics and has a chapter or two on idea validation and product road map processes. Some of the product road map processes are aimed at improving existing solutions and large budget project. That said the core lesson is more or less the same.

- Rob Fitzpatrick - book "The Mom Test". Video of him talking about the problem and solution. He describes how to create "as is" user stories so developers can design good "to be" stories. Watch how he picks features. (45 Min) <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0LwbFZkyRKk>

- Clayton Christensen - Competing Against Luck: The Story of Innovation and Customer Choice - is related, the book review I have seen suggest his process is mostly the same, but I have not read it.

Focus groups/user testing/UX - as described by <@UEQ6M68H0> above is also discussed in Microsoft secrets. - In my view, value add and ease of use are not the same. For example, word processors have become easy to use, you don't need an instruction manual or training course these days, but I remember word perfect and having to memorise key combinations for bold and centre etc.   ....  With the problem of value add, you can create a reasonable estimate of the value add of a new feature idea long before you write any code. The 3 books describe ways to do this.

Excel story ... "Over the next two weeks we visited dozens of Excel customers, and did not see anyone using Excel to actually perform what you would call “calculations.” Almost all of them were using Excel because it was a convenient way to create a table."
From  <https://www.joelonsoftware.com/2012/01/06/how-trello-is-different/>

attachments.title: Rob Fitzpatrick - How to Learn from Customers When Everyone is Lying to You
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Rob Fitzpatrick - How to Learn from Customers When Everyone is Lying to You

attachments.title: How Trello is different
attachments.text: Just a few months ago, we launched Trello, a super simple, web-based team coordination system. The feedback has been overwhelmingly positive and adoption has been very strong, even in its early, 1.…
attachments.fallback: Joel on Software: How Trello is different

text: It's a cool story and you've presented it well. I think it's a good name for a language! Building web apps still can be a hassle. What do you see the long term advantages might be? Do you think for web apps you really need a number of DSLS (frontend, routing, persistence, testing, deploying, etc)? What do you think the costs might be to develop the language tooling that would make this a net-win for users?

elements.text: It's a cool story and you've presented it well. I think it's a good name for a language! Building web apps still can be a hassle. What do you see the long term advantages might be? Do you think for web apps you really need a number of DSLS (frontend, routing, persistence, testing, deploying, etc)? What do you think the costs might be to develop the language tooling that would make this a net-win for users?
